title: 114_hr5106
content: The Seventy-ninth Congress regulations allow for the deduction of intangible drilling and development costs for geothermal deposits similar to oil and gas wells. However, this does not apply to costs already deductible under other sections. Additionally, the exclusion clause prevents major integrated oil companies from benefiting from this deduction. The amendment allows deductions for intangible drilling and development costs over a 60-month period starting from the month of payment. It applies to expenses incurred after December 31, 2015. SEC. 512 limits the percentage depletion allowance for oil and gas wells for major integrated oil companies to zero. This amendment is effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2015. SEC. 513 imposes a limitation on the deduction for tertiary injectants. The amendment to Section 193 of the Internal Revenue Code exempts major integrated oil companies from certain deductions, with the disallowed amounts being amortized over a 60-month period. Effective for expenses incurred after December 31, 2015. SEC. 514. MODIFICATION OF DEFINITION OF MAJOR INTEGRATED OIL COMPANY. The amendment to section 167(h) of the Internal Revenue Code expands the definition of a major integrated oil company to include successors in interest controlling over 50% of crude oil or natural gas production. Conforming amendments are made to ensure consistency in the tax code. The amendment to section 167(h) of the Internal Revenue Code expands the definition of a major integrated oil company. The amendments made in this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2015. SEC. 515 repeals royalty relief for outer continental shelf deep water and deep gas. SEC. 516 coordinates American Opportunity Credit and Lifetime Learning Credit with Pell Grants not used for qualified tuition and related expenses. The amendment to Section 25A(g)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 reduces qualified tuition expenses by certain scholarship amounts for an individual before other adjustments are made. The amendment to Section 25A(g)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 reduces qualified tuition expenses by certain scholarship amounts for an individual before other adjustments are made under specific chapters of the United States Code. The amendment reduces Federal Pell Grant amounts by expenses not related to tuition for eligible educational institutions. Effective starting from taxable years after December 31, 2015. The amendment expands the Pell Grant exclusion from gross income under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, specifically including Federal Pell Grants received by individuals as scholarships. This amendment applies to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2015.
